intro: Jagera serrata f. fulvinervis, commonly known as the golden-veined mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to eastern Australia. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its flattened, leaf-like stems that are often covered in a waxy coating. The plant has small, inconspicuous greenish-white flowers that are typically borne in clusters. Its berries are orange-red and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. This species plays an important ecological role by providing food for native wildlife and contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.
